facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1453 of 1969 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 29th November, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1453 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 29th November, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Writ Appeal No. 345 of 1968 and Writ Petitions Nos. 183, 249 240 of 1971 3, 105 134 of 1972.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court delivered judgment and order dated 29th November 1968 in Writ Appeal No. 345 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 29th November, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Writ Appeal No. 345 of 1968 and Writ Petitions Nos. 183, 249 240 of 1971 3, 105 134 of 1972.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 183, 249, 240 of 1971, 3, 105, 134 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental rights. V. Gupte and G. Narayana Rao, for the appellant  in  .A. 1453/69 . Niren De, Attorney General of India and P. Parameshwara Rao, for the respondent  In C.A. 1453/69 .

facts.text: The appellant and the petitioners are sugar factories in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the petitioners are sugar factories in the State of Andhra Pradesh. They applied under the provisions of section21 3  for exemption from the tax payable under sub-section  1  of that section on the ground that they, having substantially expanded, were entitled, to the extent of such expansion, to exemption from the payment of tax.

facts.text: Sugar factories applied under section 21(3) for exemption from tax under sub-section (1) on ground of substantial expansion.

anchor.surface_text: They applied under the provisions of section21 3  for exemption from the tax payable under sub-section  1  of that section on the ground that they, having substantially expanded, were entitled, to the extent of such expansion, to exemption from the payment of tax. The Government of Andhra Pradesh having refused that request these writ petitions have been filed before this Court

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is against the decision of the Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissing a writ petition filed for similar relief.

facts.text: Government policy is to grant exemption from payment of purchase tax to new and expanded sugar factories in the Co-operative Sector only.

anchor.surface_text: The present Policy of the Government is to grant exemption from payment of purchase tax to new and expanded sugar factories in the Co- operative Sector only. Besides Bobbili and Seethanagaram Sugar Factories, there are a few other sugar factories in the private sector which have also embarked on expansion programmes.

facts.text: Only new co-operative sugar factories have been granted exemption and that too only for one year.

facts.text: Quantity of sugarcane produced per acre varies: 60 tons in Maharashtra, 40 tons in Tamilnadu, far less in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that there is a difference in the sucrose companytent in the cane produced in different areas. The quantity of sugarcane produced per acre varies from 60 tons per acre in Maharashtra to 40 tons in Tamilnadu and far less in Uttar Pradesh.

issues.text: Whether the grant of exemption under section 21(3) of the Andhra Pradesh Sugarcane (Regulation of Supply and Purchase) Act, 1961 is obligatory or discretionary

anchor.surface_text: They applied under the provisions of section21 3  for exemption from the tax payable under sub-section  1  of that section on the ground that they, having substantially expanded, were entitled, to the extent of such expansion, to exemption from the payment of tax. The Government of Andhra Pradesh having refused that request these writ petitions have been filed before this Court contending that the decision denying them exemption is contrary to section 21 3  which does not countenance any classification and that the classification adopted is based on nonnexus to the object of the Act. Two contentions, one regarding promissory estoppel and another regarding the exemption given to Sarvaraya Sugars Ltd was not pressed before this Court. Though in the beginning it was urged that the grant of exemption under the section was obligatory, later the only contention, raised was that the application of each of the factories should have been considered on its merits and the State should not have fettered its discretion by laying down a policy of granting exemption only to co-operative sugar factories

issues.text: Whether the State Government fettered its discretion invalidly by adopting a policy of granting exemption under section 21(3) only to co-operative sugar factories and refusing to consider private factories on merits

anchor.surface_text: Though in the beginning it was urged that the grant of exemption under the section was obligatory, later the only contention, raised was that the application of each of the factories should have been considered on its merits and the State should not have fettered its discretion by laying down a policy of granting exemption only to co-operative sugar factories and that the policy had nonnexus to the object of the Act. Section 21 reads as follows 21.  1  The Government may, by notification, levy a tax at such rate not exceeding five rupees per metric tonne as may be prescribed on the purchase of cane required for use, consumption or sale in a factory The Government may, by notification, remit in whole or in part such tax in respect of cane used or intended to be used in a factory for any purpose specified in such notification.

issues.text: Whether the power under section 21(3) to exempt new factories and substantially expanded factories is discriminatory and violative of Article 14

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the power under s. 21 3  to exempt new factories and factories which in the opinion of the Government have substantially expanded was discriminatory and violative of Art. 14. We are unable to accept this contention. The establishment of new factories and the expansion of the existing factories need encouragement and incentives. The exemption in favour of new and expanding factories is based on legitimate legislative policy.

issues.text: Whether the policy of confining exemption to co-operative sector factories has rational nexus to the object of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Andhra Pradesh having refused that request these writ petitions have been filed before this Court contending that the decision denying them exemption is contrary to section 21 3  which does not countenance any classification and that the classification adopted is based on nonnexus to the object of the Act. The appeal is against the decision of the Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissing a writ petition filed for similar relief. Two contentions, one regarding promissory estoppel and another regarding the exemption given to Sarvaraya Sugars Ltd was not pressed before this Court.

issues.text: The short question for consideration: whether the Government of Andhra Pradesh was right in dismissing the applications claiming exemption under s.21(3)(b) for the reason of policy decision to confine benefit to co-operative sector sugar factories

anchor.surface_text: MATHEW, J.The short question for consideration in these writ petitions and the Civil Appeal is whether the Government of Andhra Pradesh was rightin dismissing the applications filed by the writ petitioners and the appellant claiming benefit of exemption from payment of the tax as provided in s. 21 3  b  of the Andhra Pradesh Sugarcane  Regulation of Supply and Purchase  Act, 1951, hereinafter called the Act for the reason that the Government has taken a policy decision to confine the benefit of the exemption to sugar factories in the co-operative sector.

holdings.text: The power under section 21(3) to exempt new factories and factories which have substantially expanded is not discriminatory and does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the power under s. 21 3  to exempt new factories and factories which in the opinion of the Government have substantially expanded was discriminatory and violative of Art. 14. We are unable to accept this contention. The establishment of new factories and the expansion of the existing factories need encouragement and incentives. The exemption in favour of new and expanding factories is based on legitimate legislative policy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification based on new/expanded factories has intelligible differentia and rational nexus to object of encouraging industry; follows prior Supreme Court precedent in Andhra Sugars Ltd.

holdings.text: Section 21(3) confers discretionary power on the Government using 'may', not obligatory grant of exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Quits clearly the discretion has been left to the State to decide whether any particular factory should be granted exemption or not. This is what this Court stated in its earlier decision. In deciding this question it is open to a Government to take into consideration the state of the industry at any particular period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'may'; policy of Act does not mandate grant; confirmed by prior judgment.

holdings.text: The Government did not invalidly fetter its discretion by adopting a policy to grant exemptions only to co-operative sugar factories, as applications were considered on merits and policy based on relevant considerations.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no reason not to accept the statement on behalf of the State of Andhra Pradesh that they have considered the request of the appellant as well as the petitioners on their merits. The, fact that after such examination they have laid down a policy of exempting only sugarcane growers factories cannot show that they have fettered their discretion,, in any way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counter-affidavit and government letter show merits consideration; policy not rigid as even co-op expanded factories denied; follows English precedents (Port of London, British Oxygen, Halsbury) allowing policy if mind kept open and relevant.

holdings.text: Co-operative sugar factories consisting of sugarcane growers form a distinct category justifying preferential treatment for exemptions.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that cooperative, sugar factories consisting of sugarcane growers fall under a distinct category different from other categories. Sugarcane growers have been the object of particular consideration and care of the legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sugarcane growers object of legislative protection; co-op factories align with policy protecting growers; rational nexus to Act's purpose.

holdings.text: The State Government properly exercised the discretion conferred by section 21(3).

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in this case the State of Andhra Pradesh has properly exercised the discretion conferred on it by the statute. The appeal and the writ petitions are dismissed-with costs, one set.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy relevant, merits considered, discretion not fettered; comprehensive review of precedents supports.

holdings.text: The appeal and writ petitions are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the majority judgment of the Court, the Court dismissed the appeal and the Writ petitions with costs, one set.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government action valid; no invalid fetter or discrimination.

holdings.text: The policy to confine exemptions to co-operative sector factories invalidly fettered discretion; applications must be reconsidered on merits without the policy.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, quash Annexure III and issue a mandamus to the Government of Andhra Pradesh in each of those writ petitions and the Civil Appeal to consider the applications of the writ petitioners and the appellant on merits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter shows no merits consideration, pre-judged by policy; policy irrelevant to incentive object; cites de Smith, precedents requiring relevance and open mind (dissenting opinion).

precedents.citation: Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. A.P. State 1968 1 SCR 505

anchor.surface_text: Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. A.P. State 1968 1 SCR 505 this Court upheld the companystitutional validity of section 21 3 and made the following observations It was next argued that the power under s. 21 3

precedents.case_name: Andhra Sugars Ltd v A.P. State
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 21(3) of the Act is constitutionally valid and the exemption power is based on legitimate policy to encourage new and expanding factories; discretion to be exercised case by case

precedents.citation: R. v. Port of London Authority 1919 1 KB 176 at 184

anchor.surface_text: R. v. Port of London Authority 1919 1 KB 176 at 184 Bankes L.J. stated the relevant principle in the following words There are oil the one hand cases where a tribunal in the honest exercise of its discretion has adopted a policy, and, without refusing to hear an applicant, intimates to him what its policy is,

precedents.case_name: R v Port of London Authority
precedents.cited_proposition: A tribunal may adopt a policy and apply it after hearing the applicant if the policy is based on legitimate reasons
precedents.cited_holding: There are on the one hand cases where a tribunal... if the policy has been adopted for reasons which the tribunal may legitimately entertain, numberobjection companyld be taken

The policy behind the Act there under companysideration was obviously to permit sale, of any article or distribution of bills or like things and in deciding that numberpermission would be granted at all the London County Council was rightly held number to have properly exercised the discretion vested in it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Authority refusing all permissions of a class exercised discretion properly where policy of Act was to permit

precedents.citation: Padfield v. Min. of Agriculture etc. 1968 1 All ER 694

anchor.surface_text: Padfield v. Min. of Agriculture etc. 1968 1 All ER 694 the refusal of the, Minister to exercise the power vested in him was companysidered as frustrating the object of the statute which companyferred the discretion and that is why a direction was issued to the Minister to companysider the appellants companyplaint according to law.

precedents.cited_proposition: Refusal to exercise discretion frustrating the object of statute is invalid

precedents.citation: British Oxygen v. Minister of Technology 1970 3 All ER 165

anchor.surface_text: British Oxygen v. Minister of Technology 1970 3 All ER 165 the whole question has been discussed at length after referring to the decisions in R. v. precedents.case_name: British Oxygen v Minister of Technology
precedents.cited_proposition: Authority may adopt policy or rule for discretion if willing to listen to applications and change if new arguments
precedents.cited_holding: the authority must number do is to refuse to listen at all. But a Ministry or large authority may have had to deal already with a multitude of similar applications and then they will almost certainly have evolved a policy

precedents.citation: R. v. Port of London Authority 1919 1 KB 176

The House of Lords was in that case companysidering the provisions of the Industrial Development Act 1966. The Act provided for the Board of Trade making to any person a grant towards approved. capital expenditure incurred by that person in providing new machi- nery or plant for carrying on a qualifying industrial process in the companyrse of the business.

precedents.case_name: R v Port of London Authority
precedents.cited_proposition: Reference to prior case on policy adoption in discretion exercise

precedents.citation: Padfield v. Minister of Agriculture 1968 1 AR ER 694

anchor.surface_text: Padfield v. Minister of Agriculture 1968 1 AR ER 694 . The House of Lords was in that case companysidering the provisions of the Industrial Development Act 1966. The Act provided for the Board of Trade making to any person a grant towards approved. capital expenditure incurred by that person in providing new machi- nery or plant for carrying on a qualifying industrial process in the companyrse of the business. After stating that the Board was intended to have a discretion and after examining the provisions of the Act the House of Lords came to the companyclusion that the Board was number bound to pay grants to all who are eligible number did the provisions give any right to any person to get a grant.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reference to prior case on frustrating statutory purpose

precedents.citation: R. v. P.L.A. ex.p. Kynoch Ltd. 1 19191 1 K.B. 176, at 184

anchor.surface_text: R. v. P.L.A. ex.p. Kynoch Ltd. 1 19191 1 K.B. 176, at 184. It was submitted that there is numberhing in the provisions of subsection 3 b to indicate that the Government companyld companyfine the benefit of the exemption only to new and expanded sugar factories in the companyperative sector fulfilling the companyditions therein special and if the Government chose to fetter the exercise of its discretion by a self-imposed rule or policy by companyfining the benefit of the exemption only to new and expanded sugar factories established or owned by companyperative societies, numberdiscretion was exercised by Government in disposing of the individual applications and that, at any rate, companysiderations foreign to the exercise of the discretion had entered into its exercise.

precedents.case_name: R v PLA ex p Kynoch Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: General rule that authority exercising discretion should number shut its ears to the application

precedents.citation: R. V. Torouay Licensing, JJ., ex. p. Brockman 1 , 1951 2 K. B. 784

anchor.surface_text: R. V. Torouay Licensing, JJ., ex. p. Brockman 1 , 1951 2 K. B. 784. Lord Goddard C.J. said The justices cannot make a rule to be applied in every case without hearing it. They may lay down for them- selves a general rule but are bound to companysider whether it is applicable to any particular case.

precedents.case_name: R v Torquay Licensing JJ ex p Brockman
precedents.cited_proposition: Justices may lay down general rule but must consider if applicable to particular case; policy must be reconcilable with Act
precedents.cited_holding: although they have a duty genuinely to exercise a discretion by companysidering each individual case on its merits, the due discharge of this duty is companypatible with the adoption of a general policy in relation to a class of cases.

precedents.citation: British Oxygen Co. Ltd. v. Ministry of Technology 3 1970 3 All E.R. 165

anchor.surface_text: British Oxygen Co. Ltd. v. Ministry of Technology 3 1970 3 All E.R. 165 the question was whether the Industrial Development Act, 1966, which provided at the relevant time that the Board of Trade may make to any person a grant towards approved capital expenditure incurred by that person in providing new machinery or plant for carrying on a qualifying industrial process in the companyrse of business, authorised the Board of Trade to frame a policy decision to refuse subsidies in respect of any item companyting less than pound 25.

precedents.case_name: British Oxygen Co Ltd v Ministry of Technology
precedents.cited_proposition: Board may adopt policy to refuse grants below certain amount if discretion unqualified and listens to applications
precedents.cited_holding: the Minister was accordingly number precluded from making such a rule or policy provided that he did number refuse to listen to an application for the exercise of his discretion.

anchor.surface_text: Merchandise Transport Ltd. vB.T.C. 1962 2 Q.B. 173 . To sum up, the policy of rule adopted by the State Government to guide itself in the exercise of its discretion must have some relevance to the object of s. 21 3 which is to provide incentive to the establishment of new industries and substantial expansion of existing industries with a view to increasing production of sugar.

precedents.case_name: Merchandise Transport Ltd v BT C
precedents.cited_proposition: Public authority must form judgment on facts of each case and number pursue consistency at expense of merits
precedents.cited_holding: Unlike a companyrt of law, it, must number pursue companysistency at the expense of the merits of individual cases

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the power under s. 21 3  to exempt new factories and factories which in the opinion of the Government have substantially expanded was discriminatory and violative of Art. 14. We are unable to accept this contention. The establishment of new factories and the expansion of the existing factories need encouragement and incentives. The exemption in favour of new and expanding factories is based on legitimate legislative policy.
ORDER In accordance with the majority judgment of the Court, the Court dismissed the appeal and the Writ petitions with costs, one set.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no reason not to accept the statement on behalf of the State of Andhra Pradesh that they have considered the request of the appellant as well as the petitioners on their merits. The, fact that after such examination they have laid down a policy of exempting only sugarcane growers factories cannot show that they have fettered their discretion,, in any way.
ORDER In accordance with the majority judgment of the Court, the Court dismissed the appeal and the Writ petitions with costs, one set.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that cooperative, sugar factories consisting of sugarcane growers fall under a distinct category different from other categories. Sugarcane growers have been the object of particular consideration and care of the legislature.
ORDER In accordance with the majority judgment of the Court, the Court dismissed the appeal and the Writ petitions with costs, one set.

We are satisfied that in this case the State of Andhra Pradesh has properly exercised the discretion conferred on it by the statute. The appeal and the writ petitions are dismissed-with costs, one set.
